description: Topics based on a study plan prepared in cooperation with a faculty supervisor. Culminates in a paper, project, comprehensive examination. Application forms must be completed and approved prior to enrollment. Maximum of three units in any one semester; may be repeated once.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: minimum of 15 upper-division Kinesiology courses completed; junior or senior standing.

title: Statistical Methods in Kinesiology
description: Statistical theory, data collection procedures, techniques for analysis and interpretation of data.

title: Research Methods in Kinesiology
description: Fundamental tools of research. Types of research, process of scientific inquiry and critical analysis of research. Topic selection and development of a research proposal.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: KNES 508 with a "C" (2.0) or better; graduate standing.

title: Evidence-Based Practice in Athletic Training
description: Introduction to the research process and evidence-based practice (EBP) in athletic training and allied health. Topics include asking clinical questions, searching for evidence and critical appraisal of the literature. Focus on the current literature to inform clinical decision-making.

title: Advanced Study of the Philosophical Perspective of Human Movement
description: Methods of the philosophical process of human movement.

title: Graduate Internship
description: On-the-job training experiences supervised by a fully trained practitioner. Minimum of 120 hours per semester plus conferences with faculty sponsor. Application forms must be completed and approved prior to enrollment. Upon completion of the internship, a written evaluation must be submitted. Not open to students on, or subject to, academic notice. Requires consent of faculty sponsor, field supervisor, field coordinator and chair.

title: Advanced Study in Physiology of Exercise
description: Current issues and research in physiology of exercise with emphasis on physiological control during acute exercise. Includes written, oral and laboratory assignments.

title: Applied Strength and Conditioning
description: Anatomical and physiological bases for programs that develop physical fitness and performance.

title: Advanced Study in Teaching Human Movement
description: Historical perspectives and current trends in pedagogical research and the resultant principles that undergird the science of teaching human movement.

title: Advanced Study in Biomechanics
description: Advanced methods and concepts associated with the quantification of human movement. Biomechanical analysis of force plate and three-dimensional video data.

title: Leadership and Administration in Athletic Training
description: Analyze the technical, practical, legal and ethical aspects of leadership and administration in athletic training and other health care organizations.

title: Athletic Training Administration Clinical Experience
description: Practical application of administrative tasks, patient care skills and clinical decision-making in various athletic training and healthcare settings. Targets healthcare-related policies and procedures, and preseason preparation as part of the sports medicine team.

title: Advanced Study in Human Motor Control and Learning
description: In-depth study of contemporary trends and issues in motor control/learning research. Application of research to practice.

title: Prevention and Management of Exercise-Related Emergencies
description: Knowledge and application of concepts related to the prevention, recognition, clinical diagnosis, and management of emergencies in sport/exercise. Hands-on patient-care skills.
prerequisites: Prerequisite: Athletic Training graduate standing. Corequisite: KNES 585 .

title: Clinical Evaluation and Diagnosis I: Lower Extremity
description: Recognizing, evaluating and diagnosing musculoskeletal pathologies in the lower extremity. Using an evidence based approach to performing a comprehensive, systematic clinical examination in the athletic training setting.

title: Clinical Evaluation and Diagnosis II: Upper Extremity
description: Recognizing, evaluating and diagnosing musculoskeletal pathologies in the upper extremity. Using an evidence based approach to performing a comprehensive, systematic clinical examination in the athletic training setting.

title: Clinical Evaluation and Diagnosis III: Head, Neck and Spine
description: Recognition, evaluation and clinical diagnosis of musculoskeletal and neurological pathologies of the head, neck and spine. Uses an evidence-based approach to performing a comprehensive, systematic clinical examination in the athletic training setting.

title: Pathophysiology of Illness
description: Recognizing, evaluating and managing systemic illnesses and other health conditions. Pharmacological considerations for treating illnesses.

title: Therapeutic Interventions I
description: Theory and application of therapeutic interventions for musculoskeletal injuries. Pathophysiology of human tissue in response to injury, the neuropathway of pain perception and the influence of various interventions on the early phases of the rehabilitation process.

title: Therapeutic Interventions II
description: Theory and application of therapeutic interventions for musculoskeletal injuries. Re-establishing normal joint mechanics and movement patterns following injury by addressing muscular strength, endurance, power and neuromuscular control. Emphasizes fitness and functional movement patterns before return-to-activity.

title: Therapeutic Interventions III
description: Theory and application of non-traditional therapeutic interventions for the treatment of musculoskeletal injuries. Topics include existing evidence for non-traditional modalities, exercise, manual therapies, pharmacotherapy, biologics, etc.

title: Advanced Study in Sport and Exercise Psychology
description: Current issues and research in sport and exercise psychology. Topics include motivation, personality, leadership and group dynamics, attention/concentration, exercise adherence/compliance, sport and exercise injury, and behavioral change strategies.

title: Consultation in Applied Sport Psychology
description: Factors related to effective consultation for enhancing athletic performance. Knowledge of consultation issues will be derived from the existing best practices and literature with the purpose of drawing practical applications for the new professional. May be repeated once for credit.

title: Advanced Study in Sociocultural Perspectives of Human Movement
description: In-depth study of the theories and methods of the sociocultural perspective and their application to the study of human movement phenomena.

title: Psychology of Injury
description: Psychological theory, research and practice in relation to the prevention, occurrence, and rehabilitation of sport injuries. Major topics include psychological risk factors for injury, psychological responses to injury, and psychological interventions to prevent injuries and enhance injury rehabilitation. Requires department consent.
prerequisites: Prerequisite: KNES 589 with a "B-" or better.

title: Emergency Management Clinical Experience
description: Practical application of patient care skills and clinical decision-making in various athletic training and healthcare settings. Complete a rotation at an assigned clinical site while supervised by a CSUF ATP preceptor. Acute care of athletic-related injuries.

title: Athletic Training Clinical Seminar I
description: Develop clinical decision-making skills within Evidence Based Practice framework. Integrate theory from didactic courses with practical experience gained during concurrent clinical rotations. Lower extremity musculoskeletal evaluation and acute care techniques.
prerequisites: Prerequisite: Athletic Training graduate standing. Corequisite: KNES 587 .

title: Athletic Training Clinical Experience I
description: Practical application of patient care skills and clinical decision-making in various athletic training and healthcare settings. Complete a clinical rotation at an assigned clinical site while supervised by a CSUF ATP preceptor.

title: Athletic Training Clinical Seminar II
description: Develop clinical decision-making skills within Evidence Based Practice framework. Integrate theory from didactic courses with practical experience gained during concurrent clinical rotations. Musculoskeletal and general medical evaluation and rehabilitative exercise techniques.

title: Athletic Training Clinical Experience II
description: Practical application of patient care skills and clinical decision-making in various athletic training and healthcare settings. Complete a clinical rotation at an assigned clinical site while supervised by a CSUF ATP preceptor.

title: Athletic Training Clinical Seminar III
description: Developing clinical decision-making skills within Evidence Based Practice framework. Integrate theory from didactic courses with practical experience gained during concurrent clinical rotations. Head and spine evaluation and techniques for evaluating efficacy of non-traditional therapies.

title: Athletic Training Clinical Experience III
description: Practical application of patient care skills and clinical decision-making in various athletic training and healthcare settings. Complete a clinical rotation at an assigned clinical site while supervised by a CSUF ATP preceptor.

title: AT Project
description: Culminating experience for AT students that requires engagement in the scholarship of application. Demonstrate the ability to identify clinical problems and apply effective, evidence-based interventions. Present projects to faculty in a public forum following project completion.

title: Athletic Training Clinical Experience IV- Immersive
description: Intensive clinical experience of the totality of care provided by athletic trainers. Participate in the full-time, day-to-day role of an AT as appropriate for the clinical setting while supervised by a CSUF ATP preceptor.

title: Project
description: Directed independent inquiry. Not open to students on, or subject to, academic notice. Requires classified graduate standing, successful completion of an oral presentation of the project, and signature of all committee members on or before the census date of the semester in which the student elects to enroll.

title: Thesis
description: Student will select and have approved a research proposal, conduct the research, and prepare a formal analysis and report. Not open to students on, or subject to, academic probation. Requires classified graduate standing, successful completion of an oral presentation of the thesis, and signatures of all committee members on or before the census date of the semester in which the student elects to enroll.

title: Graduate Independent Research
description: Student research in a specific area of human movement studies. Application forms must be completed and approved prior to enrollment. Upon completion of the research, a written report must be submitted. Not open to students on, or subject to, academic notice. May be repeated for a maximum of 3 units. Requires consent of the faculty adviser and chair.

title: Fundamental Korean-A
description: Develop listening and reading comprehension, speaking and writing, and cultural awareness to communicate on a basic level. Introduction to Korean customs, culture and civilization. Conducted primarily in Korean.

title: Health Psychology
description: Biopsychosocial (biological, psychological, social) processes that affect the physical and mental condition of human beings. Health promotion, prevention, evaluation, treatment  (patients in treatment settings, patient-provided dynamics), chronic and terminal illness, and cultural influences on health and healthy care delivery. PSYC 351 is recommended.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: PSYC 101 , three upper-division psychology courses (PSYC 351 recommended) all with a "C" (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

title: Psychopharmacology
description: Basic neurophysiological principles of pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics that underlie the effects of drugs on experience and behavior. Recreational drugs and abused drugs that can contribute to psychological disorders. Psychological, medical and social implications of pharmacotherapy.

title: Racial/Ethnic Health Psychology
description: Preventing disease/illness and promoting health psychology for racial/ethnic persons living in the U.S. (e.g., Latinx, Black/African American, Asian/Asian American, Native American/Indigenous, Middle Eastern, North African communities). Racism as a stressor affecting health. Interventions to reduce community health disparities.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: PSYC 101 and completion of three upper-division psychology courses; or graduate standing.

title: MARC Proseminar
description: Intended to increase the contact of MARC Fellows with minority scientists of national repute who will present seminars. Fellows will read and discuss relevant primary literature, attend the seminars, and meet with speakers before and after the seminars. May be repeated for a maximum of 4 units. Requires selection as a MARC Fellow. (BIOL 480M, CHEM 480M and PSYC 480M are the same course.)

title: Survey of Clinical Psychology
description: Methods, diagnosis, therapeutic techniques, research, educational requirements, professional requirements, ethics, graduate school preparation, choosing graduate programs.

title: Personnel Psychology
description: Comprehensive survey of the psychological approaches applied to personnel recruitment, selection, job design, utilization, training performance criteria, separation and retention of personnel in the workplace.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: PSYC 101, PSYC 391; or graduate standing.

title: Organizational Psychology
description: Comprehensive survey of approaches to organizational culture, structure and change. Focus on organizational behavior, such as teamwork, leadership, motivation, job satisfaction, conflict, power and management strategies.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: PSYC 101, PSYC 391; or graduate standing.

title: Teaching of Psychology
description: Experience in communicating research, theory, and applications of psychology, with emphasis on individual tutoring. Section 1 (Undergraduate Course Assistantship) includes additional aspects of course instruction; Section 2 (Peer Mentors) includes various outreach services. May be repeated for credit (not for major or minor) towards graduation for a maximum of 6 units.

title: Field Placement in Psychology
description: Supervised experience in which psychological principles or methods are applied in a fieldwork setting. Mandatory class meetings to discuss and write about experiences of integrating psychological theory with practice. Required of majors.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: nine units of 300-level psychology courses at CSUF by course registration; 2.0 GPA in psychology courses.

title: Independent Research
description: Study plan must be approved by university census date. Individual empirical research or library investigation under the supervision of a faculty member. No more than three units of credit toward the major. May be repeated for credit toward graduation. Requires consent of Instructor.

title: Issues and Perspectives in Psychological Research
description: Current theoretical, professional and methodological issues in psychology.

title: Professional and Legal Issues
description: Introduction to methodological, ethical and legal issues in the field of Clinical Psychology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite: M.S. Clinical Psychology graduate standing.

title: Career and Lifestyle Development
description: Survey of career and lifestyle development throughout the lifespan. Major theories and strategies in career counseling. Integrating knowledge of career development with the practice of counseling. (COUN 502 and PSYC 502 are the same course).

title: Research Design
description: Principles and methods of planning and carrying out systematic psychological research, interdependence of research design and statistical evaluation of results. Practice in formulating testable hypotheses.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: PSYC 201 , PSYC 465 with a "B-" (2.7) or better; or graduate standing.

title: Seminar: Advanced Topics in Psychological Research
description: Content of seminar may vary each semester. A topic is selected for in-depth study from one or more specialty areas within the field of psychology. May be repeated with different topics for a maximum of 9 units.

title: Addictions Counseling
description: Etiology and treatment of addictive behaviors (e.g. substance abuse, gambling). Biological, psychological and systemic factors. Current approaches to assessment, intervention, prevention programs and relapse prevention, including Motivational Interviewing. Role of co-occurring disorders. Using community resources to help client and client's family. (COUN 535 and PSYC 535 are the same course).
prerequisites: Prerequisites: COUN 500 , COUN 511A ; or COUN 500 , COUN 511B ; or PSYC 501 , PSYC 545 .

title: Crisis and Traumatic Stress: Theory, Research, and Intervention
description: Overview of the crisis and traumatic stress fields, with an emphasis on intervention. History of the fields, the effects of exposure to traumatic stress, and approaches to assessing and ameliorating maladaptive outcomes.

title: Advanced Psychopathology
description: In-depth study of diagnosis, etiology theories, research and prevention of adult and child psychopathology.
prerequisites: Prerequisite: M.S. Clinical Psychology graduate standing.

title: Theories of Psychological Intervention
description: Psychology (Clinical) program. In-depth coverage of psychotherapy. Principle theoretical approaches covered are: psychodynamic, humanistic, and behavioral/ cognitive behavioral.
prerequisites: Prerequisite: M.S. Clinical Psychology graduate standing.

title: Psychotherapy Techniques
description: Psychology (Clinical) program. Skills course in conducting diagnostic interviews and basic therapeutic techniques. Role playing and video feedback. (2 hours lecture, 3 hours laboratory)
prerequisites: Prerequisites: PSYC 501 , PSYC 545 , PSYC 547 all with a grade of "B-" (2.7) or better.

title: Marriage, Family and Child Therapy
description: Psychology (Clinical) program. Marriage, family and child therapy: theory, techniques and research.
prerequisites: Prerequisite: M.S. Clinical Psychology graduate standing.

title: Group Psychotherapy
description: Role of interpersonal learning and communication in the behavior change and skill development in group psychotherapy. Lecture, discussion, role plays and videos will focus on psychoeducational groups in an ethical and diversity-sensitive framework.
prerequisites: Prerequisite: M.S. Clinical Psychology graduate standing.

title: Child and Adolescent Treatment
description: Psychology (Clinical) program. Specific therapy techniques, including behavioral, and general approaches to the treatment of children and adolescents.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: PSYC 501 , PSYC 545 , PSYC 547 all with a "B-" (2.7) or better.

title: Clinical Psychology Assessment
description: Psychology (Clinical) program. Theory, administration, scoring and interpretation of measures of intelligence and objective personality inventories.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: PSYC 461 with a "B-" (2.7) or better; or graduate standing in clinical psychology.

title: Intimate Partner and Couples Counseling
description: Treating intimate partners and couples, including overview of current theories, assessment, goal-setting, interventions, ethical issues and diversity issues. Assessing and treating intimate partner violence. Sexual dysfunctions and sex therapy. (COUN 562 and PSYC 562 are the same course)

title: Cross-Cultural Psychology
description: Cross-cultural issues as they apply to clinical psychology, specifically psychotherapy. Practical, research and theoretical issues.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: PSYC 501 , PSYC 545 , PSYC 547 all with a "B-" (2.7) or better.

title: Fieldwork
description: Psychology (Clinical) program. Supervised clinical work in mental health agencies. (Minimum of 12 hours field experience per week.) Must be taken for a letter grade. (Course may be repeated by third-year students. Repetition will not count toward study plan units and should be taken CR/NC.)
prerequisites: Prerequisites: PSYC 548 , PSYC 560 all with a "B-" (2.7) or better.

title: Fieldwork
description: Psychology (Clinical) program. Supervised clinical work in mental health agencies. (Minimum of 12 hours field experience per week.) Must be taken for a letter grade. (Course may be repeated by third-year students. Repetition will not count toward study plan units and should be taken CR/NC.)
prerequisites: Prerequisite: PSYC 594A with a "B-" (2.7) or better.

title: Thesis Research
description: Supervised individual major research project, written as a thesis and presented and defended successfully to a faculty thesis committee. Consent of thesis adviser required.

title: Independent Graduate Research
description: Empirical research in a selected area of psychology. Design, conduct and write with the collaboration of a member of the faculty. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Requires supervising research instructor consent.

title: Personal Health
description: Basic concepts relating to health and well-being from a holistic perspective. Mental, emotional, physical and socio-environmental dimensions of health, sexuality and relationships; nutrition and physical fitness; use and abuse of drugs; health care services and current health problems.

title: Introduction to Environmental Health and Safety
description: How environmental and safety hazards influence public health and sustainability. Multiple perspectives on water, air, and solid waste pollutions, sustainability and public safety issues.

title: Introduction to Aging Studies
description: Multidisciplinary overview of: characteristics, strengths and problems of older persons; diversity in aging process involving gender, race, ethnicity, subculture; services to older adults; gerontology as an academic discipline and a field of practice. (AGNG 133, SOCI 133, PUBH 133, HUSR 133 and PSYC 133 are the same course.)

title: Introduction to Public Health
description: Introduction to the discipline of public health. Basic concepts and terminologies of public health. Topics include community health; environmental and occupational health; epidemiology; and healthcare policy and management.

title: Exploration of Health and Allied Health Professions
description: Overview of health-related professions in the U.S., including the healthcare system and major current concerns. Career exploration into health and allied health professions, including occupational, academic and extracurricular preparation. Develop knowledge to enhance preparation for graduate school.

title: CPR, Automated External Defibrillator and First Aid
description: Provides knowledge and skills necessary to respond to injuries and sudden illnesses in the community. Successful completion provides American Red Cross certifications in infant, child and adult Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPR), Automated External Defibrillator (AED) and standard first aid. Credit/No Credit only. (PUBH 203 and KNES 203 are the same course)

title: Integrative Health
description: Theoretical and philosophical foundations of integrative health. Differences between biomedical and integrative approaches to health promotion, prevention, and treatment, Eastern and Western therapies, and various global medical systems.
prerequisites: Prerequisite: junior or senior standing; or Pre-Health Professions minor.

title: Promotion of Optimal Health
description: Advanced health concepts and practices. Common health problems, causative factors and methods for prevention. Preventive and promotive health concepts and practices; integrating physiological, psychosocial, spiritual, cultural and environmental factors that inhibit or facilitate optimal health. Elective for nursing majors only.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: GE Area 1A or 1C; not freshman standing.

title: Latinx Health
description: Identification and examination of sources of health disparities and inequities among Latinxs; intersectionality; and health promotion best practices grounded in Latinx cultural capital and strengths.
prerequisites: Pre-requisites: PUBH 201, minor in Public Health or Pre-Health Professions. Co-requisite: PUBH 320.

title: Public Health and the Environment
description: This course introduces essential concepts in environmental health by exploring the impact of food production, transportation, and individual lifestyle choices on public health.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: non-freshman; completion of any Biology or Chemistry course in GE Area 5A or 5B

title: Concepts in Public Health
description: Theoretical and practical issues of public health as a profession. Resources, roles in various settings, ethical issues, academic and professional development in public health.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: Public Health major; not freshman standing.

title: Drugs and Society
description: Psychoactive substances from an interdisciplinary perspective. Social, historical, biological and legal aspects of substance use.

title: Violence in Public Health Context
description: The problem of violence from a public health perspective. Characteristics and epidemiology of major forms of violence that levy significant burden on public health across populations in various geographic settings. Public health approaches to preventing violence and reducing its harm.
prerequisites: Prerequisite: PUBH 201 with a "C-" (1.7) or better.

title: Consumer Health
description: Analyze and evaluate health information, products and services; medical quackery, fraudulent health practices, and laws and agencies protecting the consumer.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: GE Area 1A or 1C; not freshman standing.

title: Barrios and Health
description: Links between urban environments and health. How community development and the grassroots help shape health in barrios. Requires service learning with non-profit organizations. (CHIC 338 and PUBH 338 are the same course.)

title: Stress Management
description: Nature of stress and physiological and psychological effects of prolonged stress responses. Short- and long-term somatic and behavioral techniques (exercise, relaxation, meditation, nutrition, time management and goal setting) for management of stress. (PUBH 342 and KNES 342 are the same course.)

title: Measurement and Statistics in Health Science
description: Measurement theory and statistics used to evaluate health and human performance, focusing on analyzing and interpreting data in different environments. Lecture, discussion, cooperative learning and field observation. Active participation and experiential learning.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: GE Area 1A or 1C; not freshman standing.

title: Applied Measurement and Statistics in Health Science
description: Designed to give practical experience answering fundamental public health questions that arise in health science. Builds on concepts learned in PUBH 349, using quantitative methods and real-world datasets.
prerequisites: Pre- or corequisites: Public health major; PUBH 349.

title: Nutrition
description: Concepts of nutrition as they relate to nutritional needs, practices and problems throughout the life cycle. Nutritional counseling and education of individuals/groups toward health promotion and disease prevention.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: non-freshman; completion of any Biology or Chemistry course in GE Area 5A or 5B

title: Physical Activity and Lifelong Well-Being
description: Integrating physiological, psychological and sociological understandings of the human being in relationship to physical activity as a lifelong pursuit. Physical fitness, nutrition, stress reduction, socialization, and individual differences in human behavior. (PUBH 353 and KNES 353 are the same course.)

title: Contemporary Issues in Children's Health
description: Overview of common causes of, interrelationships between, and prevention of morbidity and mortality among children and youth; preventive and promotive health concepts and practices; connections between health and learning are explored.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: GE Area 1A or 1C; not freshman standing.

title: Climate Change and Global Health
description: Explore global health outcomes of climate change through social-ecological systems that influence patterns of infectious and chronic diseases worldwide. Cross-cutting themes, such as health equity and justice.

title: Peer Mentoring for Public Health Student Success
description: Develop mentorship skills through seminar learning and serving as a peer mentor to fellow students. Enhance communication, cultural competency, leadership, motivational, goal achievement, personal managementand student success skills.Barriers to and resources for college student success. Requires mentor application approval.

title: Program Design in Kinesiology and Health Promotion
description: Provides skills necessary for developing, implementing and evaluating human movement and/or health promotion programs for specific target populations.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: PUBH 349 , PUBH 349L ; or Public Health minor.

title: Epidemiology
description: Applying epidemiologic procedures to the understanding of the occurrence and control of infectious and chronic diseases, mental illness, environmental health hazards, accidents and geriatric problems.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: PUBH 320 ; PUBH 349 , KNES 349 or SOCI 303 .

title: Introduction to the U.S. Healthcare System
description: Addresses concepts related to U.S. health services organization, delivery, financing, and quality assessment and improvement. Historical influences and trends, contemporary challenges, and strategies to address these challenges are examined.

title: Worksite Injury Prevention and Rehabilitation
description: How work style, equipment, and environment contribute to worksite musculoskeletal injuries. Strategies that can minimize human error, injuries, discomfort and dissatisfaction through injury prevention and rehabilitation of the worker.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: KNES 202 or PUBH 320 ; junior or senior standing; or graduate standing.

title: Community Health Education
description: Multiple settings for community health education practice and professional roles and skills that are required for health educators. Identification of community health education concepts with application to various segments of the nation's health.
prerequisites: Prerequisite: PUBH 320 ; or Public Health or Pre-Health Professions minor.

title: Promoting Health in Diverse Populations
description: Impact of cultural variables on health/illness. Current and potential strategies to improve health care delivery to underrepresented groups. Identifying cultural competence skills that are essential for health educators.
prerequisites: Prerequisite: PUBH 320 ; or Public Health or Pre-Health Professions minor; or graduate standing.

title: Environmental Health
description: Overview of environmental factors such as noise, water and land pollutions, pests and contaminants that influence human and ecological health on the regional scale. Methods of control to prevent diseases from environmental agents.
prerequisites: Prerequisite: PUBH 320 or Public Health minor.

title: Global Issues in Environmental Health
description: Overview of environmental factors, such as air pollution, population dynamics, urbanization and energy production, that influence human and ecological health on the global scale. Methods of control to prevent diseases form environmental agents.
prerequisites: Prerequisite: PUBH 320 , Public Health minor or graduate standing.

title: Chronic Disease Epidemiology
description: Areas in chronic disease epidemiology, the leading causes of death and disability, and the risk factors related to causes and the prevention of disease. May be repeated once for credit.

title: Infectious Disease Epidemiology
description: Applies epidemiological concepts to the study and control of infectious diseases in human populations. Epidemiological profile, including agents, modes of transmission, occurrence, clinical characteristics and prevention methods of specific infectious disease.

title: Statistical Programming for Health Data Management and Visualization
description: Provides applied statistical programming, data management and visualization skills for epidemiology and public health using real-world health data. Experience interpretating and communicating epidemiology and public health data programming outputs.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: PUBH 349, KNES 349, SOCI 303, or MATH 120; PUBH 349L; Public Health Major.

title: Health Policy
description: Health policy actors and processes in the United States. Roles of Congress, the President, bureaucracy and interests groups in health policy and policy process are explored, including an introduction to policy analysis. (PUBH 424 and POSC 424 are the same course).

title: Alternative Healing Therapies
description: Framework for understanding the philosophies, principles and use of alternative healing therapies. Includes analyzing research to demonstrate effectiveness and experiential learning.
prerequisites: Prerequisite: PUBH 320 or Public Health minor.

title: Spirituality and Health
description: Relationship between spirituality and health. Topics include: relevance of spirituality in one's life; impact of spirituality on decision making, health behavior; relationship of spirituality and health throughout lifespan; links between spirituality, health outcomes; diverse spiritualities.
prerequisites: Prerequisite: PUBH 320 , Public Health minor or graduate standing.

title: Determinants of Health Behavior
description: Contemporary research on the health effect of human behavior. Introduction to theoretical foundations and practical applications of behavior in the context of health: physical, psychological, cultural and social health. Current issues and theories of health behavior.
prerequisites: Prerequisite: PUBH 320 or Public Health minor.

title: Applied Health Promotion in Aging Populations
description: Promotion/risk reduction program content, development, implementation and evaluation. Topics include weight control, stress management, substance abuse, physical fitness and accident prevention. (PUBH 450 and AGNG 450 are the same course.)
prerequisites: Prerequisites: PUBH 320 ; junior or senior standing; or Kinesiology or Sociology major; or Public Health or Gerontology minor; or graduate standing.

title: Designing Health Education Curricula
description: Theory and skills necessary to develop curriculum based on analysis of individual, community and societal needs and interests.

title: Worksite Health Promotion
description: Philosophy, rationale and guidelines for developing health promotion programs in the corporate setting. Unique considerations in assessing needs, planning and implementing programs, evaluating effectiveness and coordinating activities in the workplace are discussed. (PUBH 460 and KNES 460 are the same course.)
prerequisites: Prerequisites: PUBH 320 or KNES 202 ; not freshman standing; or Public Health minor; or graduate standing.

title: Occupational Health and Safety
description: Occupational health principles, including anticipation, recognition, evaluation and control of occupational hazards are presented to heighten awareness of workplace hazards on human health. Occupational health laws, regulations and methods of compliance.
prerequisites: Prerequisite: PUBH 320 , Public Health minor or graduate standing.

title: Toxicology in Public Health
description: Fundamental toxicological concepts, including absorption, distribution, storage, biotransformation and elimination of toxicants, target organ toxicity and risk assessment. Toxicological effects of environmental agents, such as pesticides, industrial chemicals, household chemicals and food contaminants.
prerequisites: Prerequisite: PUBH 320 , Public Health minor or graduate standing.

title: Air Pollution and Health
description: Health effects of air pollutants on local, regional, and global scales are addressed. Health effects of urban smog, particulate matter, indoor, outdoor, and occupational exposures. Health implications from global warming, ozone-depletion and acid rain.
prerequisites: Prerequisite: PUBH 320 , Public Health minor or graduate standing.

title: Introduction to International Health
description: Issues in international health emphasizing core disease conditions. Introduction to leading causes of death and disability within an international context, as well as programmatic and policy responses to improve international health.
prerequisites: Prerequisite: PUBH 320 , Public Health minor or graduate standing.

title: Hazardous Materials, Regulations and Emergency Response
description: Principles of hazardous material management, hazardous waste handling and chemical emergency response. Understand chemical classifications and waste disposal requirements; analyze federal and state environmental health and safety regulations; and evaluate exposure mitigation strategies and emergency response planning and execution.

title: Food Safety
description: Overview of public health response in safeguarding and investigating food safety issues and food-borne illnesses. Discussion of various requirements in managing a food protection program to identify and prevent important biological and chemical agents of foodborne illnesses.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: PUBH 320 , GE Area 5B; Public Health minor; or graduate standing.

title: Fundamentals of Industrial Hygiene
description: Introduction to essential industrial hygiene concepts; various hazards or environmental contaminants encountered in the workplace; exposure evaluation methods and effective controls.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: PUBH 320 , Public Health minor; or graduate standing.

title: Childhood Obesity, Nutrition and Social Context
description: Multidisciplinary approach to understanding childhood obesity in diverse/underserved populations, including basic biological processes, the role of nutrition, health consequences and cultural factors associated with childhood obesity.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: PUBH 350 ; PUBH 320 or Public Health, Pre-Health Professions or Food Studies minor; or graduate standing.

title: Nutritional Assessment
description: Overview of nutritional assessment. Gain practice in and understand four primary nutritional assessment techniques: anthropometric, biochemical, clinical and dietary.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: PUBH 350 ; PUBH 320 or Public Health, Pre-Health Professions or Food Studies minor; or graduate standing.

title: Public Health Planning, Research and Evaluation
description: Identify and apply foundational methodological concepts in research used in public health. Research designs, sampling, data collection and analytic strategies, reporting, valid sourcing and ethical considerations.

title: Transdisciplinary Perspectives on HIV/AIDS
description: Multilevel examination of the HIV/AIDS pandemic from the perspectives of several disciplines within an overarching public health framework. Analysis at the levels of individuals and physical, social-structural and cultural environments.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: PUBH 320 , PUBH 401 ; or graduate standing.

title: Health in a Global Society
description: Health effects of globalization. Health concerns arising from political, economic and social interconnectedness and the need to find common solutions to ensure human health worldwide.
prerequisites: Prerequisite: PUBH 320 , Public Health minor or graduate standing.

title: Health Science Practicum
description: A requirement for health science majors offering an opportunity to plan, implement and evaluate special community-based projects under faculty supervision. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Credit/no credit only.

title: Internship in Public Health
description: Supervised observation and field experience in community health settings as conducted by government, voluntary, professional or industrial/corporate organizations. May be repeated once for credit.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: PUBH 320 ; all PUBH 400-level classes except PUBH 475 ; senior standing.

title: Independent Study
description: Topics based on a study plan prepared in cooperation with a faculty supervisor. Culminates in a paper, project, comprehensive examination or performance. Application forms must be completed and approved prior to enrollment. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units; only three units in any one semester.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: minimum of 15 upper-division Public Health courses; junior or senior standing.

title: Issues in Public Health
description: Historical perspectives, definitions and discussion of current public health issues. Prepares public health professionals to draw on knowledge and skills from a variety of disciplines to define, critically assess, evaluate and resolve public health problems.

title: Advanced Methods in Epidemiology
description: Advanced application of epidemiologic procedures to the understanding of the occurrence and control of diseases and other health problems. Emphasis is given to study design, data quality, statistical analysis and causal inference.

title: Communicating for Public Health Practice
description: This course introduces students to the applied study of communication theory and data visualization to improve the public?s health. Explores varied modalities of both written and oral communication including online dissemination, focusing on tailoring messages and mediums to intended audiences.

title: Measures and Methods in Public Health
description: This course introduces concepts and methods to describe population patterns of health and their determinants. Students will focus on what to measure, how to measure, and minimizing bias. These concepts and skills are used to critically analyze public health data.

title: Qualitative Research and Field Methods in Health
description: Theory, epistemology, sampling, data collection, data analysis and reporting results in qualitative research and evaluation. Field work in communities and applications to health.

title: Research Methods in Public Health
description: Fundamental tools of research. Types of research, process of scientific inquiry and critical analysis of research. Topic selection and development of a research.

title: Advanced Environmental Health
description: Ecological impacts of human activities and the need to control factors that are harmful to human health. A framework is provided for investigation/management of health hazards. Principles of environmental health emphasizes the relationships between population, natural resources, disease, toxicology and pollution.

title: Public Health Administration
description: Principles, practices and skills essential to successful public health administration. U.S. health care system and factors that shape it. Public health services and administration, patterns of diseases, managed care, ethics and quality of care.

title: Program Planning and Evaluation
description: Comprehensive theories and methods for planning and evaluating health promotion programs. Techniques for collecting and analyzing quantitative and qualitative data. Skills for measuring effectiveness of health promotion programs. (PUBH 535 and AGNG 535 are the same course)
prerequisites: Prerequisite: Public Health or Aging Studies graduate standing.

title: Advanced Study in Health Promotion and Disease Prevention
description: Psychological, social, ecological, economic and political theories relevant to the mission and process of health promotion. Applying behavioral change techniques and health education methodology to health promotion targeting individuals and whole communities.

title: MPH Student Internship
description: Apply classroom knowledge to practical problems in the field, acquire additional knowledge and skills, carry out a mutually beneficial project, produce a written analytical evaluation and interact regularly with public health professionals.

title: MPH Integrative Learning Experience
description: Faculty-mentored, student-driven project that synthesizes program foundational and emphasis competencies into an integrated learning experience resulting in a high-quality written product.

title: Thesis
description: Student will select and have approved a research proposal, conduct the research and prepare a formal analysis and report. Not open to students on, or subject to, academic probation. Requires graduate classified status, successful completion of an oral presentation of the thesis and signatures of all committee members on or before the census date of the semester in which the student elects to enroll.

title: Graduate Independent Research
description: Student research in a specific area of public health. Application forms must be completed and approved prior to enrollment. Upon completion of the research, a written report must be submitted. Not open to students on, or subject to, academic notice. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units; only 3 units in any one semester. Requires consent of the faculty adviser and chair.

title: Management of Acute and Critical Conditions in Obstetrics
description: Incorporate triage theory and advanced pathophysiology concepts into diagnosing and managing acute and critical obstetric conditions to inform advanced practice in women's health care.

title: Women's Health Care: Newborn Assessment and Management
description: Assessing and managing newborns through the first 28 days of life.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: Nursing Women's Health Care MS student; NURS 570 , NURS 572 , NURS 573A .

title: Internship in Intermediate Nurse Midwifery Practice
description: Clinical application of knowledge in midwifery practice for childbearing women and newborns with moderate to high risk factors. Co-management and collaborative management. Clinical management of women needing gynecologic and primary care.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: NURS 570 , NURS 572 , NURS 573A . Corequisites: NURS 574 , NURS 576 .

title: Intermediate Women's Health Care Practicum
description: Clinical application of knowledge in Advanced Practice Nursing for care of women with moderate to high risk conditions in pregnancy. Co-management and collaborative management. Clinical management of women needing gynecologic and primary care. (Minimum 9 hours practicum per week)

title: Advanced Nurse Midwifery Internship
description: Synthesis of clinical knowledge and skill for advanced practice in women's health. Residency incorporates full scope practice and primary care to prepare for independent practice as a nurse-midwife.
prerequisites: Prerequisite: successful completion of all didactic and clinical courses related to the Nurse Midwifery specialty.

title: Advanced Women's Health Care Practicum
description: Synthesis of clinical knowledge and skill for advanced practice in women's health. Residency incorporates full scope practice and primary care to prepare for independent practice as a women's health care nurse practitioner. (Minimum 9 hours practicum per week)
prerequisites: Prerequisite: successful completion of all courses related to specialty.

title: Fellowship in Midwifery and Women's Health Practice
description: For certified nurses in advanced midwifery and women's health care, focusing on independent practice, research and/or health policy development. Student will be mentored by an established certified nurse-midwife or nurse practitioner for completion of objectives.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: completion of all courses required for MSN and completion of midwifery, midwifery/nurse practitioner, or nurse practitioner certification.

title: Professional Role for the Advanced Practice Nurse as a Midwife or Nurse Pract.
description: Critical thinking and decision-making theory specific to issues in women's health care. Professional, ethical, legal, public policy aspects of nurse practitioner/nurse-midwifery practice. Legal basis of practice, national international trends in women's health care, developing strategic business skills, promoting the profession.
prerequisites: Prerequisite: second-year graduate standing in Women's Health Care.

title: Comprehensive Clinical Practicum
description: Low- to high-risk patient assessment and management through case study and skills lab competency. Simulated patient evaluation/management and comprehensive examination demonstrating student's application of knowledge and skills. A full-year course over two semesters. (Minimum 6 hours per week per semester)

title: Comprehensive Clinical Practicum
description: Low- to high-risk patient assessment and management through case study and skills lab competency. Simulated patient evaluation/management and comprehensive examination demonstrating student's application of knowledge and skills. A full-year course over two semesters. (Minimum 6 hours per week per semester) Requires consent of instructor.

title: Project
description: Identify specific issues/problems in degree concentration; develop and complete project.

title: Project
description: Identifying specific issues/problems in degree concentration; developing and completing project. May be repeated for a maximum of 4 units.

title: Thesis
description: Individual research with conferences with instructor, culminating in a thesis.

title: Independent Graduate Study
description: Independent inquiry resulting in oral or written report. May be repeated with different content for a maximum of six units.

title: Theoretical Perspectives for Advanced Nursing Practice
description: Theories in nursing and other health care disciplines with particular emphasis on utility in practice; evaluate specific theoretically based strategies for individual nurse or patient change and those for planned changes within organizations.

title: Data Management, Quality Improvement and  Evaluation for Advanced Nursing Practice
description: Provides necessary skills and knowledge to use evidence and health data for quality improvement in a health setting. Uses quality systems to evaluate change and common methods used in quality improvement processes.

title: Advanced Evidence-Based Practice in Nursing
description: Reading, interpreting and evaluating studies using quantitative and qualitative methods in nursing and other health care disciplines; develop initial literature review for integrative scholarship proposal.

title: Leadership, Management and Economics in Advanced Nursing Practice
description: Analyzing leadership theories and organizational models within healthcare delivery systems. Principles of change theory, financial management, strategic planning, program development and implementation. Fiscally sound leadership management in providing healthcare for individuals and populations.

title: Epidemiology and Clinical Prevention
description: Applying epidemiological principles and approaches related to health and illness in at-risk populations. Use epidemiological models and inquiry to determine population needs and promote interventions to enhance health-related quality of life and prevent illness.

title: Informatics in Healthcare
description: Use information systems/technology resources to implement quality improvement initiatives and support practice and administrative decision-making. Standards and principles for selecting and evaluating information systems and patient care technology and related ethical, regulatory and legal issues.

title: Healthcare Policy, Ethics and Advocacy for Nurses
description: How national and international health policies, advocacy efforts, ethics and economics impact health care delivery and its outcomes and influence advanced practice nursing. Development of health care policy, delivery models, reimbursement mechanisms and economic perspectives.

title: DNP Clinical practicum: Professional Role Development
description: Supervised clinical opportunities in selected clinical settings to enhance professional role development in advanced nursing practice. Synthesize prior graduate learning experience; focus on evidence-based best practices to enhance safety, quality and efficiency in the student's nursing specialty area. May be repeated for a maximum of 18 units.

title: Advanced Practice Nurse in Pathophysiology
description: Principles of normal body functioning, pathophysiologic and psychological changes occurring with altered health across life span. Clinical case studies utilized to demonstrate the pathophysiologic bases for assessment and management of common health problems.

title: Advanced Practice Nurse Health Assessment
description: Application of theoretical concepts related to comprehensive health assessment of patients across the lifespan.
prerequisites: Prerequisite: DNP standing; NURS 641. Corequisite: NURS 642L.

title: Advanced Practice Nurse Health Assessment Laboratory
description: Clinical application of advanced health assessment skills and strategies necessary for advanced practice nursing role in a particular area of specialization. This course is a laboratory course.
prerequisites: Prerequisite: DNP standing; NURS 641. Corequisite: NURS 642.

title: Advanced Practice Nurse Clinical Pharmacology
description: Advanced course of pharmacology and pharmacotherapeutic content and application relevant to the advanced practice nurse.
prerequisites: Prerequisites:  DNP standing; NURS 641, NURS 642, NURS 642L.

title: Advanced Practice Nurse Primary Care: Acute Problems
description: Theory and research related to the most basic and common acute or episodic problems affecting patients and families across the lifespan. Concepts of quality health care, health promotion, disease management, resource management and shared-decision making.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: DNP standing; NURS 640, NURS 641, NURS 642, NURS 642L, NURS 643.Corequisite: NURS 648L.

title: Advanced Practice Nurse Primary Care: Acute Problem Practicum
description: Clinical field study applying theory and research, while developing skills related to providing care to individuals with preventive, acute, episodic health conditions in selected primary care settings off campus. Collaborative management.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: DNP standing; NURS 640, NURS 642, NURS 642L.Corequisite: NURS 648.

title: Nursing Curriculum Development
description: A systematic study of principles of curricula for nursing academic programs, patient education, and staff development. Education philosophies, objectives, selection and organization of learning experiences and evaluation methods.

title: Instructional Design in Nursing Education for Doctor of Nursing Practice (DNP) Students
description: Course design; using instructional strategies, simulation and technology in classroom and online teaching environments; assessing and evaluating student learning. Ethical, legal and cultural competencies for nurse educators. Requires consent of instructor.

title: Common Procedures in Primary Care
description: Clinical lab simulation for common procedures performed in primary care clinical practice. Pelvic exams, prostate exams, PAP smears, IUD insertion/removal and cervical biopsies. Joint aspirations/injection, X-ray interpretation and suturing.
prerequisites: Prerequisite: DNP standing, NURS 641, NURS 642, NURS 642L, NURS 643.

title: Advanced Practice Nurse Primary Care of Women:  Obstetric Health
description: This course focuses on theory and research related to the obstetrical health care needs. Assessment, management, and education/counseling needs of women during pregnancy are emphasized. Social, physiological, legal and ethical issues associated with pre- and postnatal care are included.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: DNP standing; NURS 641, NURS 642, NURS 642L, NURS 643, NURS 648, NURS 648L, NURS 653. Corequisite: NURS 654L.

title: Advanced Practice Nurse Clinical Practicum:  Obstetric Health
description: Clinical application of theory and research through clinical experiences in selected primary care settings designed to provide students with competencies in the assessment, diagnosis, management, and education/counseling in selected OB and Gynecological populations.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: DNP standing; NURS 641, NURS 642. NURS 642L. NURS 643, NURS 648, NURS 648L, NURS 653. Corequisite: NURS 654

title: Advanced Practice Nurse Primary Care of Pediatrics
description: This course focuses on the study of common health problems affecting pediatric patients and their families.  Emphasis includes theory and research related to comprehensive assessment, appropriate clinical decision making, differential diagnoses, management, and patient/family education of common pediatric health problems.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: DNP standing; NURS 641, NURS 642, NURS 642L, NURS 643, NURS 648, NURS 648L, NURS 653, NURS 654, NURS 654L. Corequisite: NURS 658L.

title: Advanced Practice Nurse Pediatric Clinical Practicum
description: Clinical field study applying theory, research and developing clinical skills in selected populations within primary care settings. Emphasizes developmental needs of clients in relation to family, social and cultural structures in caring, managing care and treating pediatric clients.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: DNP standing, NURS 641, NURS 642, NURS 642L, NURS 643, NURS 648, NURS 648L, NURS 653, NURS 654, NURS 654L. Corequisite:  NURS 658.

title: Primary Care of Adult/Geriatric Patient with Chronic Health Problems
description: Common acute and chronic health problems affecting geriatric clients. Theory and research related to comprehensive assessment, appropriate clinical decision making, treatment options and differential diagnosis.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: DNP standing; NURS 641, NURS 642, NURS 642L, NURS 643, NURS 648, NURS 648L, NURS 653, NURS 654, NURS 654L, NURS 658, NURS 658L. Corequisite:  NURS 660L

title: Primary Care of Adult/Geriatric Patient with Chronic Health Problems Clinical
description: Clinical practicum applying theory, research, and developing clinical skills related to the care of adult and elderly patients and their families diagnosed with acute or chronic healthcare problems. Emphasis includes assessment, diagnosis, management, patient/family education, lifestyle modification and counseling strategies.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: DNP standing; NURS 641, NURS 642, NURS 642L, NURS 643, NURS 648, NURS 648L, NURS 653, NURS 654, NURS 654L, NURS 658, NURS 658L. Corequisite:  NURS 660.

title: Advanced Pharmacology for Anesthesia I
description: Pharmacology and physiology as an integral part of modern anesthesia practice. The pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics, pharmacotherapeutics, pharmacy and toxicology of intravenous medications and anesthetic gases used for induction of anesthesia.

title: Anesthesia Basic Principles
description: Introduction to the art and science of anesthesia. Provides introductory knowledge and psychomotor preparation prior to commencing a clinical residence.

title: Anesthesia for Surgical Procedures and Special Populations
description: Selected scientific foundations of anesthesia practice, focusing on cardiopulmonary and renal systems.

title: Advanced Physiology for Nurse Anesthetists
description: Cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, neurological, hematological and cellular physiology; emphasizing how these systems relate to anesthesia management.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: NURS 542 , NURS 542L . Corequisites: NURS 682 , NURS 684 , NURS 685L .

title: Advanced Pharmacology for Anesthesia II
description: Pharmacology and physiology as an integral part of modern anesthesia practice. Pharmacodynamics pharmacokinetics, pharmacotherapeutics, pharmacy, toxicology of muscle relaxants, narcotics, beta and alpha adrenergics, and autonomic nervous system drugs.

title: Nurse Anesthesia Practicum I
description: Supervised increasingly complex clinical experience to provide clinical application of the foundational principles in anesthesia: 6 hours of practicum per week.

title: Pediatric and Obstetric Anesthesia
description: Instruction and assessment of the anatomy, physiology and pathophysiology of the pediatric and obstetric patient. Anesthesia considerations and case management strategies for several types of pediatric and obstetric surgical and non-surgical procedures.

title: Nurse Anesthesia Practicum II
description: Supervised increasingly complex clinical experience provides clinical application of principles in anesthesia. (15 hours practicum per week.)

title: Advanced Pathophysiology for Anesthesia I
description: Cardiac and pulmonary pathophysiology for anesthesia practice. Anesthesia case management for each disease process and the use of current evidence to guide practice. Regional anesthesia principles and lab. Acute and chronic pain management principles relating to anesthesia practice..

title: Nurse Anesthesia Practicum III
description: Supervised increasingly complex clinical experience provides clinical application of the foundational principles in anesthesia. (18 hours practicum per week)

title: Advanced Pathophysiology for Anesthesia II
description: Incorporates the pathophysiologic basis for anesthesia management, including neurologic, endocrine, and gastro-intestinal care. Integrates concepts of pharmacology related to anesthesia and the application of current scientific research findings in these populations.

title: Nurse Anesthesia Practicum IV
description: Supervised increasingly complex clinical experience provides clinical application of the foundational principles in anesthesia (18 practicum hours per week.)

title: Professional Nurse Anesthesia Role: Comprehensive Clinical Integration
description: The professional component of nurse anesthesia practice emphasizing ethical, medical and legal responsibilities of the practitioner, including various aspects that impact the profession of nurse anesthesia. Review of anesthesia topics for national anesthesia certification examination. May be repeated for a maximum of 9 units.

title: Nurse Anesthesia Residency
description: Culminating preceptored clinical experience provides clinical practice in all areas of anesthesia management. (18 hours practicum per week)

title: Advanced Pharmacology III
description: Pharmacology and physiology as an integral part of modern anesthesia practice. Pharmacodynamics pharmacokinetics, pharmacotherapeutics, pharmacy, toxicology of adjunct drugs, including antibiotics, diabetic agents, antiretrovirals, asthma medications, cardiac medications and antihypertensives.

title: Seminar in Integrative Clinical Scholarship
description: Proposal Development as applied to clinical scholarly work for DNP project. Course requires 95 hours in a clinical setting with faculty consultation. Outcome is a proposal for a scholarly clinical doctoral project.

title: Integrative Clinical Scholarship I: Evidence-Based Practice
description: Under supervision of a faculty project chair. Clinical project on a topic in student's areas of interest and specialization. Role of DNP in clinical inquiry and evaluation, and related leadership. Principles of proposal writing as applied to clinical problems.

title: Integrative Clinical Scholarship II: Evidence-Based Practice
description: Implementing DNP project within a clinical setting, using theory integration and evidence-based change from nursing science and other disciplines. Incorporating principles of practice inquiry, evidence-based practice, and/or practice inquiry. Integrating core DNP concepts and competencies.

title: Integrative Clinical Scholarship III: Evidence-Based Practice
description: Evaluating and completing DNP project within a clinical setting. Incorporating principles of practice inquiry, evidence-based practice, and/or practice inquiry. Integrating core DNP concepts and competencies.

title: Independent Doctoral Study
description: Independent doctoral level inquiry in nursing resulting in oral or written report.

title: Fundamental Persian-A
description: Develop listening and reading comprehension, speaking and writing, and cultural awareness to communicate on a basic level. Introduction to Persian customs, cultures and civilization. Conducted primarily in Persian.

title: Fundamental Persian-B
description: Continued introduction to Persian culture. Students express themselves in oral and written forms at a basic/intermediate level about cultural topics, such as technology, art, daily activities, work environment, leisure, travel and multiculturalism. Conducted primarily in Persian.

title: Directed Study
description: Supervised research projects in Persian language, literature, culture, linguistics or business. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Requires consent of instructor and department chair.

title: Independent Study
description: Supervised research projects in Persian language, literature, culture, linguistics or business. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units. Requires consent of instructor and department chair.

title: Introduction to Philosophy
description: Nature, methods and some of the main problems of philosophy. Primarily for freshmen and sophomores. Not a prerequisite for advanced courses.

title: Meaning, Purpose, and the Good Life
description: Introduction to Western and Eastern approaches to perennial topics in philosophy concerning human flourishing and the nature of persons. Questions considered include, "What is happiness?" "What is the good life?" "Does life have meaning and purpose?" and "What is a person?"

title: Critical Thinking
description: Developing non-mathematical critical reasoning skills, including recognition of arguments, argument evaluation and construction of arguments.

title: Introduction to Logic
description: Logical structure of language and correct reasoning: deduction, induction, scientific reasoning and informal fallacies.

title: Religions of the World
description: Introduction to at least five religious world views from an historical and comparative perspective, with descriptive analyses of their belief systems, moral codes and symbolic rituals: Judaism, Christianity, Islam, Hinduism, Buddhism and Sikhism. (RLST 110 and PHIL 110 are same course.)

title: Introduction to Ethics
description: Problems of human conduct and moral evaluation: standards for moral assessment of conduct and persons; morality and its relation to mores, social demands and personal commitments.

title: Explore Core: Truth
description: Nature, significance and knowability of truth, exploring perspectives from philosophy, history, journalism, criminal justice, mathematics, engineering and the natural sciences. How is truth made or discovered? And why and when we should we trust the truths that emerge? (PHIL 133, BIOL 133, EGME 133, LBST 133 are the same course.)

title: Video Games, the Arts and Philosophy
description: Introduction to art, visual art, games and game theory. Aesthetics of games and interactive visual media. Epistemic and moral relations of virtual worlds to reality. Ultimate value of game-play and visual arts to life's meaning and purpose.

title: History of Philosophy: Greek Philosophy
description: Origins of Western philosophy and its development through Socrates, Plato and Aristotle.

title: History of Philosophy: Medieval Philosophy
description: Study of philosophies from Late Antiquity through the Renaissance and Reformation. Topics include: Hellenistic philosophy, Scholasticism, and rise of Christian, Jewish, and Islamic philosophy. Figures include: Plotinus, Augustine, Maimonides, Avicenna, Catherine of Siena, Thomas Aquinas, and William of Ockham.

title: History of Philosophy: Rationalism and Empiricism
description: Rationalism of Descartes, Spinoza and Leibniz, and the empiricism of Locke, Berkeley and Hume.

title: History of Philosophy: Kant and the 19th Century
description: Rationalism and empiricism as a background to Kant. Revolutionary aspects of Kant's critical philosophy. Subsequent trends in 19th century philosophy, emphasizing such figures as Hegel, Schopenhauer, Marx, Mill, Kierkegaard and Nietzsche.

title: Gender and Sexuality Studies
description: Interdisciplinary introduction to women's issues and research in relevant disciplines. (GSS 302 and PHIL 302 are the same course.)

title: Introduction to the Philosophy of Science
description: The ongoing debates within philosophy of science about the claims of scientific progress, and the limits of scientific knowledge and the scientific method, with an eye on the impact of science on society and of society on science.
prerequisites: Prerequisite: GE Area 5A or 5B; or lower-division philosophy course.

title: Aesthetics: Philosophy of Art and Beauty
description: Conditions and aims of art and of aesthetic experience.

title: Business and Professional Ethics
description: Nature and limits of the moral rights and responsibilities of business and the professions (including law, medicine, science, engineering, journalism, management and teaching).

title: Environmental Ethics
description: Conceptual and moral foundations of environmental ethics, focusing on ecosystem and wildlife conservation policies, animal rights, a land ethic, competing policy analyses and obligations to future generations.

title: Medical Ethics
description: Ethical issues raised by recent technical developments in medicine and of the moral rights and responsibilities of patients and health-care professionals.

title: Philosophical Argument and Writing
description: Philosophical concepts, distinctions and methods are used to teach philosophical and argumentative writing that is clear, critical, expressive and precise. Designed to satisfy the classroom portion of the upper-division writing requirement for philosophy majors.

title: Contemporary Moral Issues
description: Applying ethical and social/political theories to contemporary moral problems. Topics selected from current issues in law, business, medicine, sexual morality, and gender/multicultural studies, including abortion, racism, crime, punishment, welfare, domestic violence and pornography.

title: Ethics, Artificial Intelligence and Robots
description: Ethical issues related to technological advancements of AI and robotics. Topics include: AI?s accountability, transparency, implicit biases, value alignment; robots? ethical guidelines and potential moral/legal status; and possible massive human job displacement resulting from AI and robotics.

title: Existentialism
description: Introduction to existentialist perspectives on freedom, meaning, responsibility, authenticity and self-deception. Typically includes discussion of Kierkegaard, Nietzsche, Heidegger and Sartre.

title: Philosophy of Sex and Love
description: Philosophical approaches to love, friendship, marriage and eroticism. Nature of love, relationship between sexuality and love, gender roles and gender equality. Investigates ethical and legal controversies in sexuality, marriage and privacy.

title: Evolution and Creation
description: Interdisciplinary study of evolutionary biology's impact on culture in context of religious doctrines of creation. Evolutionary theory and religious and philosophical reactions from Darwin to the present, including relevant educational and legal contexts. (PHIL 333 and LBST 333 are the same course.)

title: Philosophy of Feminism
description: Philosophical speculations on how the difference of gender and sex is relevant to every area of human life. What does it mean to be a woman, to be the gender and embodiment of female?  What do women know? (PHIL 343 and GSS 343 are the same course.)
prerequisites: Prerequisite: three units of philosophy or gender and sexuality studies.

title: Social and Political Philosophy
description: Individualism, community, freedom, authority, justice, human rights and alienation, from the perspective of social and political theory.

title: Philosophy, Literature and Cinema
description: Aesthetics of literature and film, emphasizing how storytelling deepens our imagination and understanding of identity, culture, society and values through use of word and image.

title: Asian Philosophy
description: Asian philosophies such as Taoism, Confucianism and Buddhism (especially Zen): world views, conceptions of human nature and the good life. Applications to martial and non-martial arts. Comparisons with Western philosophies, religions and values.

title: Philosophy and Law in America
description: Moral issues in American law, including free speech, affirmative action and punishment. Influence of politics on legal reasoning and the Constitution. Tension between legal reasoning and equal treatment under the law, and how philosophical theories of law respond to this.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: completion of GE Area 1A, 1B or 3B.

title: First Course in Symbolic Logic
description: Recognition and construction of correct deductions in the sentential logic and the first-order predicate calculus.

title: Meaning and Mind
description: Philosophical issues about language and mind, including topics such as meaning, reference, truth, speech act and belief. (PHIL 375 and LING 375 are the same course).
prerequisites: Prerequisite: six units of philosophy or six units of linguistics or three units of each.

title: Philosophical Approaches to Race, Class, and Gender
description: Despite the history of analyzing race, class, and gender as separate phenomena, the three are integrally connected. Focus on the interstitial connections among the three to gain knowledge of the formation of race, class and gender.

title: American Philosophy
description: Examines and critiques significant philosophical themes, texts, and trends in the philosophy of the Americas in the late 19th and early 20th century, especially the classical pragmatists (e.g. Peirce, James, Dewey, Addams, DuBois), and their contemporary interpreters (e.g. Misak, Haack, Talisse).

title: Marx and Marxism
description: Marx and his followers in philosophical perspective. Theories of human nature, society and intellectual activity; conceptual tools for the analysis of social phenomena; sources; and followers, both critical and dogmatic.

title: Postmodernism
description: Such modern and post-modern movements as phenomenology, hermeneutics, critical theory, post-structuralism, deconstruction, the Frankfurt school and French feminism; influences of these movements on political, literary and psychoanalytic theory.

title: Directed Study
description: Supervised individual study as an elective. May be repeated with different content for a maximum of 6 units. No more than 3 units may be taken with any one adviser in any one semester. Requires approval of department.

title: Ethical Theory
description: Major ethical theories as advanced by such authors as Aristotle, Kant, Mill and Rawls.

title: Metaphysics
description: Metaphysics and metaphysical issues such as reality, universals, space, time, substance, identity and difference, causality, permanence and change, freedom and determinism, minds and bodies.

title: Phenomenology
description: Ephemeral structure of experience and subjectivity. Conceptualizations of the subject, consciousness, embodiment and engagement with the world. Primary figures include Edmund Husserl, Martin Heidegger and Maurice Merleau-Ponty.
prerequisites: Prerequisite: PHIL 315 ; any lower-level course in philosophy.

title: Plants and Life
description: Importance of plants in our lives, including plant domestication and the origin of agriculture. Why plants are fascinating organisms. No credit toward biological science major.

title: Biology of Human Sexuality
description: Biology of the human reproductive system, sexual differentiation, anatomy and physiology, sexual behaviors, procreation, contraception and sexually transmitted infections. No credit toward biological science major.

title: Human Anatomy
description: Systems approach to the structure and function of the human body. For biological science majors and related health sciences. (2 hours lecture, 6 hours laboratory)
prerequisites: Prerequisites: Biology major - BIOL 251 , BIOL 253L , BIOL 252 , BIOL 254L , CHEM 120B with a "C" (2.0) or better. Other major - BIOL 251 or BIOL 252 , CHEM 120B with a "C" (2.0) or better; or BIOL 310 with a "B" (3.0) or better.

title: General Human Physiology
description: Fundamental mechanisms of human physiology. Integrating cellular and organ system functions, emphasizing regulatory processes. For biology majors and related health sciences. (3 hours lecture, 3 hours laboratory).
prerequisites: Prerequisites: Biology major - BIOL 251 , BIOL 253L , BIOL 252 , BIOL 254L , CHEM 120B ; Biochemistry major - BIOL 151 , BIOL 251 , CHEM 120B ; other major - BIOL 151 , BIOL 152 , BIOL 251 , BIOL 253L all with a "C" (2.0) or better.

title: Scientific Communication Workshop
description: Instruction and practice in written and oral scientific communication, including retrieval, citation and evaluation of relevant literature.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: Biology major - BIOL 251, BIOL 253L, BIOL 252, BIOL 254L, CHEM 120B, all with a "C" (2.0) or better; other major - junior or senior standing.

title: Seminar in Biology Education
description: For students interested in biology education/science education. Discuss major topics in biology education and conduct research. (3 hours lecture/discussion)
prerequisites: Prerequisite: BIOL 302 , BIOL 303 , BIOL 309 , BIOL 314 or BIOL 325 with a "C" (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

title: Biogeography
description: Evolutionary patterns and mechanisms of the distribution of plants and animals in the major habitats of the world. Current concepts and theories.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: BIOL 314 or BIOL 325 with a "C" (2.0) or better; or Biology or Environmental Studies graduate standing.

title: Computer Lab in Molecular Systematics
description: Gain practical and theoretical experience with software-based methods in molecular systematics, with emphasis on Internet resources for molecular biologists, acquisition of gene protein sequences, multiple sequence alignment, PCR primer design, phylogenetic analysis and controversies in the field. (2 hours lecture, 3 hours laboratory)
prerequisites: Prerequisite: BIOL 303 , BIOL 309 , BIOL 314 or BIOL 325 with a "C" (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

title: Developmental Biology
description: Molecular and cellular processes in embryonic development encompassing mechanisms of fertilization, cell and tissue interactions, morphogenesis, organogenesis and the regulation of gene expression.
prerequisites: Prerequisite: BIOL 303 or BIOL 309 with a "C" (2.0) or better; or Biology graduate standing.

title: Evolutionary Genetics
description: Introduction to molecular genetic data analysis as commonly applied in the fields of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology. Classical population genetics through to the genomics era, focusing on conservation.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: BIOL 251 , BIOL 253L , BIOL 252 , BIOL 254L , all with a "C" (2.0) or better; or graduate standing.

title: Medical Genetics and Systems Biology
description: Advances in genetics, genomics, proteomics and systems biology. Implications for the pharmaceutical industry, the clinic and for genetic counseling. Uses of biological arrays in diagnosing and treating diseases.
